image.altText: A man is seen bleeding from his head while emergency services are on board

props.synopsis: As the details of the devastating injuries sustained onboard flight SQ321 emerge, attention is turning to what happens to these passengers and crew now and what can be done to make all the hours spent in an aircraft cabin safer.

title.children: Turbulence caused 'life-changing' injuries for dozens of passengers. Now, flying could change

image.altText: Grey-headed flying fox caught in netting over a fruit tree.

props.synopsis: Fruit tree netting with large holes is now prohibited in Canberra backyards, with residents facing fines of up to $800 if caught using it. Netting must now have a mesh size of 5mm by 5mm or smaller.

title.children: Fruit tree netting that can entangle flying foxes and birds now banned in Canberra backyards

image.altText: A courtroom sketch of Greg Lynn

props.synopsis: Forensic specialists and a frail widow give evidence in the trial of Greg Lynn, accused of murdering Russell Hill and Carol Clay.

title.children: Jurors in the trial of accused murderer Greg Lynn were warned the details would not be for the faint of heart

image.altText: Jason Horne-Francis looking at the football

props.synopsis: In his 50th game, Jason Horne-Francis is up against the side who drafted him first overall, as Port Adelaide looks to continue the Kangaroos' miserable losing streak to start the season. Follow live.

title.children: Horne-Francis makes big admission ahead of 50th game as Port faces Kangaroos

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: QT: Port leading after late flurry to end quarter
QT: Blues with the early break after fast start
Johnston rips out backflip after a goal

image.altText: A woman holds a child with medical equipment taped to its head

props.synopsis: Recorded cases of respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) have nearly doubled on last year across Australia, as a "whole bunch of viruses" continue to circulate throughout the country.

title.children: A 'whole bunch of viruses' are circulating at the moment. Here's what you should look out for

image.altText: a crowd of people walking on a dirty road, two people carry a stretcher made out of tree branches.

props.synopsis: More than 100 people are believed to have been killed in a landslide that buried a village in a remote, mountainous part of Papua New Guinea, with helicopters the only way of accessing the region.

title.children: Landslides hampering rescue efforts in remote PNG village, where more than 100 are believed dead

image.altText: An earth-moving machine at work at a mine site.

props.synopsis: Kurt Hourigan, 37, died following a collapse at Ballarat Mine in March that also left a colleague seriously injured. General manager Peter Crooks has now resigned, though the reason for the decision is unclear.

title.children: Gold mine general manager resigns months after deadly rockfall

image.altText: Jim Chalmers holds a copy of the 2024 Budget papers as he arrives at Parliament House

props.synopsis: In the past 10-15 years, there has been bipartisan support for a range of decisions that profoundly increase the cost of government. Yet the hysterical alarm at increases in the size of government spending fail to acknowledge this.

title.children: Hysterical alarm at increases in government spending fails to acknowledge the elephant in the room

image.altText: Greyhound legs and lower torso while the animal is running.

props.synopsis: Greyhound industry figures discussed breeding so many dogs it would become impossible to shut down the industry due to welfare issues, in secret recordings tabled in South Australia's Parliament.

title.children: 'The more dogs the harder it is for them to shut industry down': Secret greyhound recordings in SA Parliament

image.altText: RBA reno 1

props.synopsis: Renovating the Reserve Bank's headquarters is increasingly looking like a disastrous episode of home building show Grand Designs. The key difference? The budget for the horror reno is now north of $1 billion.

title.children: The Block and Grand Designs have nothing on the RBA's billion-dollar renovation horror show

image.altText: two photos of stores with the text "copy & paste?" in the middle

props.synopsis: Accusations of copycatting have been levelled by two small businesses operating close to each other in the same street in Sydney's Newtown.

title.children: New Sydney store accused of copying its neighbour 500 metres up the road

image.altText: Kale and Karin Robinson and their five school age sons.

props.synopsis: With the cost-of-living crisis forcing numerous small businesses to close, Charters Towers couple Karin and Kale Robinson are thriving against the odds, navigating the retail meat industry while raising five boys.

title.children: There are no staff at this self-service butcher shop and it runs 24/7

image.altText: A model train in front of scenery

props.synopsis: Peter Michalak has already spent a decade creating a model version of the broad gauge Adelaide to Victoria rail line in his rumpus room and says he has at least another 10 years to go.

title.children: After 10 years, more than $20k and many 'burnt fingers', Peter's model train project is taking shape

image.altText: Emergency services and traffic at a suburban street.

props.synopsis: A third person has died after being rushed to hospital following a shooting Perth's western suburbs.

title.children: Three people dead after shooting in Floreat, in Perth's west

image.altText: Fire truck and two firefighters outside a burnt home, scene is taped off

props.synopsis: A man has been killed and a woman has been seriously injured in a house fire in Adelaide's south.

title.children: Man dead in Adelaide house fire, woman taken to hospital with injuries

image.altText: From cover of Where is the Green Sheep? by Mem Fox and Judy Horacek. With three colourful sheep running down a hill

props.synopsis: It's been two decades since Where Is the Green Sheep? hit shelves, but the classic Aussie children's book has lost none of its sparkle. Here's how it first came to be.

title.children: 'Nearly every kid knows it,' but this bestseller almost didn't happen — until Mem Fox had a brainwave

image.altText: An illustration of two women from behind, sitting before a magistrate. One has their arm around the other.

props.synopsis: A small room within a Sydney courthouse is packed full of women who have experienced domestic violence and the workers trained to help them make sense of legal process. Inside it, the true scale of the crisis is laid bare.

title.children: The safe room at Liverpool Court is packed full on Tuesdays. It reveals the true scale of the DV crisis

image.altText: Four Israeli tanks drive in a line, with small Israeli flags flying from them.

props.synopsis: The International Court of Justice orders Israel to halt its military offensive in southern Gaza in a landmark ruling which is unlikely to have any impact on the ground.

title.children: Australia backs landmark UN court ruling for Israel to halt Rafah offensive

image.altText: olive oil being poured into a small bowl with olives next to it

props.synopsis: Shoppers have been receiving a shock in recent weeks when reaching for olive oil, which is for many a standard pantry staple. But never fear, as there are alternatives that could save you some well-needed cash.

title.children: I can no longer afford olive oil. What else can I use?

image.altText: Charred pages of books amid rubble

props.synopsis: A "bright yellow spark" and then an explosion — residents of Kharkiv, just kilometres from the Russian border, are bracing for further onslaughts.

title.children: Ukraine's second-largest city facing new onslaught as Russia prepares for 'larger offensive'

image.altText: A walker on a tightrope between two rocky outcrops at sunrsie

props.synopsis: A group of thrillseekers rigged up a high-line near the top of the Stirling Range, a rugged group of mountains that tower over the surrounding lowlands in Western Australia's south.

title.children: Highliners 'walk on air' during epic crossing — and one of them was naked

image.altText: Dennis Dunn stands in front of a St Mary's club honour board.

props.synopsis: AFL Northern Territory removed football legend Dennis Dunn's name from one of the most prestigious awards in NT football, over a conviction that's almost a decade old. His supporters are calling for the decision to be reversed.

title.children: 'Nobody remembers it, now everybody knows it': Anger as champion's name stripped from award for 2016 conviction

image.altText: A South Koran man in a room looking despondent.

props.synopsis: Almost a quarter of a million South Koreans have withdrawn from the outside world. Meet two of them.

title.children: Wren lived in his walk-in-wardrobe for three months. He's what's known as a 'shut in'

image.altText: Jaimen sits at the top of a staircase in his wheelchair

props.synopsis: Only 1 per cent of Australia's beaches are accessible to those who live with disabilities. Jaimen Hudson, who broke his neck trying to get to the beach, says that needs to change.

title.children: The first time Jaimen broke his neck he became quadriplegic. Then he broke it again

image.altText: Billy Frampton holds his hands on his head

props.synopsis: Fremantle kicked the last four goals to snatch a dramatic draw against injury-hit Collingwood, but it didn't come without controversy, and the Magpies want answers.

title.children: 'You're not allowed to do that': Collingwood 'confused' over late free kick

image.altText: Valentine Holmes celebrates a try

props.synopsis: Valentine Holmes is set to play in Queensland's State of Origin series opener after avoiding a ban for a hip-drop tackle against Wests Tigers.

title.children: Holmes avoids Origin ban as inconsistency 'annoys the crap' out of Cowboys coach

image.altText: A man wearing a black polo shirt and white apron stands behind a barbecue cooking a steak.

props.synopsis: The heat has been put on Network Ten in a Senate inquiry into greenwashing and executives refused to put a number on a controversial gas sponsorship deal for its successful MasterChef show.

title.children: 'Gas lobby forced-fed down our throat': MasterChef grilled in greenwashing Senate inquiry

image.altText: Man on phone, in warm-coloured room, with lamp on in background

props.synopsis: Degrading behaviour towards women is common in 'mainstream' pornography, according to Australia's eSafety commissioner. What sort of impact is this having on teenagers and adults?

title.children: 'Men have to be the brutalisers': What are the impacts of misogynistic porn?

image.altText: Man dressed in a suit with his head bowed

props.synopsis: A New Mexico judge rejects a request by Alec Baldwin to drop a criminal charge against him during a fatal shooting on the film set of Rust. The decision clears one of the last remaining hurdles for prosecutors to put the Hollywood actor on trial for involuntary manslaughter in July.

title.children: Judge rejects Alec Baldwin's request to drop criminal charge

image.altText: Landscape photo of pagodas and rock formations, with two small hikers on a trail

props.synopsis: Accommodation pods, communal huts, and bathrooms are part of a plan to develop a paid hiking experience in a protected area.

title.children: Private bush campsites planned near Blue Mountains hiking route divides 'haves and have-nots', critics say

image.altText: Morgan Spurlock smiling

props.synopsis: Oscar-nominated documentary filmmaker Morgan Spurlock, who made food and American diets his life's work by famously eating only at McDonald's for a month to illustrate the dangers of a fast-food diet, dies from complications related to cancer.

title.children: Super Size Me filmmaker Morgan Spurlock dies aged 53

image.altText: an artist's impression of a marina

props.synopsis: The Gateway Marina on the edge of the Great Barrier Reef has gone into liquidation owing millions of dollars to creditors, while investors wait to see what happens next.

title.children: $250m luxury marina development near Great Barrier Reef collapses, leaving buyers in limbo
